page.title: 17Rhuddlan/Historic Sites
page.content: Rhuddlan is a town situated near the mouth of the River Clwyd and takes its name from the reddish colour (rhudd) of the river bank (glan).In the area are to be found numerous sites of historic importance. {Twt Hill}also known locally as {Bonc {Hill}- site of Norman 'motte and bailey' castle built in 1073. {Abbey Farm}on {Abbey Road}-{Dominican {Friary}was situated on this site. {Remains of a Norman Church}were discovered on what are now the school playing fields at {Ysgol y Castell}. {The Medieval Bridge}which still carries all traffic through Rhuddlan despite concern about stress is a stone structure, built in 1595.The flow of traffic is such that the need for a{'by-pass'}has been emphasised for over 10 years.
